content.statement: Functors appear throughout mathematics: power set P: Set→Set, free group F: Set→Grp, forgetful functors U: Grp→Set, fundamental group π₁: Top→Grp, and homology functors H_n: Top→Vect.

explanation.intuition: Mathematical functors capture systematic ways of building new structures from old ones. The power set functor builds 'sets of subsets', the free group functor builds 'the freest group possible' from a set, forgetful functors 'forget' structure.
explanation.key_insight: Functors formalize common mathematical constructions. Many natural operations (taking subsets, building free objects, forgetting structure) are actually functors - structure-preserving transformations between categories.
explanation.technical_details: Each example maps objects and morphisms while preserving composition and identity. Power set maps sets to their power sets and functions to their inverse images. Free functors build free algebraic structures. Forgetful functors strip away structure.

concrete_examples.name: Power set functor P: Set→Set
concrete_examples.morphism_mapping: Function f: A→B ↦ P(f): P(A)→P(B) where P(f)(S) = {f(s) | s ∈ S}

concrete_examples.name: Free group functor F: Set→Grp
concrete_examples.object_mapping: Set X ↦ F(X) = free group on X
concrete_examples.morphism_mapping: Function f: X→Y ↦ unique group homomorphism F(f): F(X)→F(Y)

concrete_examples.name: Forgetful functor U: Grp→Set
concrete_examples.morphism_mapping: Group homomorphism h ↦ underlying function h
concrete_examples.verification: U forgets group structure, keeping only sets

concrete_examples.name: Fundamental group π₁: Top→Grp
concrete_examples.object_mapping: Topological space X ↦ fundamental group π₁(X)
concrete_examples.morphism_mapping: Continuous map f: X→Y ↦ induced homomorphism f₊: π₁(X)→π₁(Y)

concrete_examples.name: Homology functors H_n: Top→Vect
concrete_examples.object_mapping: Topological space X ↦ n-th homology group H_n(X)
concrete_examples.morphism_mapping: Continuous map f ↦ induced linear map f₊

sources.citation: Mac Lane, S. (1971). Categories for the Working Mathematician. Springer.
Awodey, S. (2010). Category Theory (2nd ed.). Oxford University Press.

cross_domain_references.note: This programming concept APPLIES mathematical concepts from their native domains

applies.applicationContext: Functors in programming apply the mathematical concept of structure-preserving mappings between categories
